metadata.title: Hey, Can (A)I Get Your Number?. Using CNNs to help love flourish in the… | by Murto Hilali | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: (Unless you were born after 2000, in which case you avoid calling people at ALL costs— just text them, weirdo.) Now you look like Stevie Wonder and you can’t see SH*T, much less the digits on this…

all_paragraphs: Okay, look. They just met you — and this is crazy.
But you somehow just got their phone number, so now you gotta call them…maybe.
(Unless you were born after 2000, in which case you avoid calling people at ALL costs— just text them, weirdo.)
There’s only one problem. You just got Lasik eye surgery:

Now you look like Stevie Wonder and you can’t see SH*T, much less the digits on this piece of paper. In your despair, you look left and right, searching for an elevated surface you can hurl yourself off of before realizing you still can’t SEE ANYTHING.
But wait. This isn’t the end. You’ve got a workaround: a plan so crazy, it just might work —
You’re going to use artificial intelligence.
Wait, what? AI!? How is Wall-E going to help you right now?
See, that’s a bit of a misconception — AI doesn’t necessarily mean robots.
Artificial intelligence describes computers executing tasks that humans can do.

Tasks such as “seeing” pictures of handwritten digits and identifying what numbers they are. When it comes to image classification, we usually use a kind of structure called a convolutional neural network, or a CNN. Check out this article for an in-depth analysis on how they work — but here’s a brief summary:
So, how exactly do you leverage this amazing technology?
Luckily, you’re a whiz with a keyboard and don’t even need to see the screen to do this — here’s how it breaks down:

Kaggle is a data science competition platform where you can find free datasets. Normally, you’d have to get pictures of handwritten numbers, convert them into .csv files containing their features, then run that through a model to train it.
Luckily, we don’t have to do that just yet — you can get that data here, from the MNIST dataset. We’ve also gotta add some of the dependencies that give us the tools to make this happen:
In your lifetime, if you only saw 1 rabbit and 39,999 ducks, you might guess that that’s a duck. Conversely, if you saw 1 duck and 39,999 rabbits, you’d guess rabbit.

Machines learn similarly to how you learn — if the data is biased/unbalanced towards a certain label, it could lead to inaccurate predictions. We need to make sure the data is distributed evenly so that the machine learns all 10 digits the same.
You can do this with some simple python commands:
Looks like your data is distributed pretty evenly already, so you’re good to go!
We’ve got to make our dataset workable, so we normalize and reshape it such that it works with the model we’re going to use later. Then, we encode our labels (10 digits) into vectors:
Now let’s split the data up further into training and validation set:
We’re going to be using the Keras Sequential API for this problem, and it comes together a bit like this:

What we’re doing here is adding the layers that our data is going to go through. Now we set up an optimizer and annealer to avoid over-fitting. We can also enhance and expand our dataset to avoid this further:
Now let’s put it all together!
Yay! Through your eyes that are somewhat recovering from the surgery, you can see that the model is about 96% accurate.
You’re almost there. The only thing between you and your and romantic destiny is being able to actually use this model to figure out what that phone number is.
Somehow, you’ve managed to take photos of the individual digits that make up that phone number and uploaded them to your computer, you clever rascal:

Your first job is to turn their pixel values into a format that your model can read. That means you need a script to put each of these photos in .csv form, in the same format as your training dataset.
This should create a .csv file in the same folder that you can feed into your model. Let’s do that now:

WHOA. You did it. Holy crap. You’re a genius. A messiah. A hero among men. You stand up from your laptop, do a victory lap, give your dog a high-five. The numbers on the right tell you what the phone number is, which you can FINALLY see because your eyesight is back.
(Sure, that might mean this whole exercise was unnecessary but roll with me on this.)
You pick up your phone and begin to dial those sweet, sweet digits when you realize…
there is no way this is a real number.”
Oh well…maybe someone else will be impressed by your data science skills?

Hi, I’m Murto and I’m a 17-year-old entrepreneur and student in Toronto, Canada. If you have any feedback for me on this article, or if you just want to chat, please reach out to me on LinkedIn! Next steps:
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
20-y/o tech enthusiast/work in progress. All things STEM, business, and behaviour.
